awd_titl_txt: Extremal Combinatorics and Ramsey Theory in Structured Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project focuses broadly on the area of combinatorics, and the questions under consideration are characterized by their connections to several different fields of mathematics. One of the main aims of this project is to explore these connections, and to synthesize techniques from different areas and bring them to bear on some longstanding open problems. Much of the planned work is concerned with the properties of large discrete structures, and the questions of interest in this project are relevant to the study of disordered systems that may be modeled by such structures, such as collections of interacting particles, large networks like the internet, or the human brain.

There are two primary areas under investigation, namely extremal combinatorics and Ramsey theory. The project will investigate questions in extremal combinatorics that involve additional structure, with a focus on algebraic, number-theoretic, and topological structure. The project will also address questions of a Ramsey-theoretic nature that additionally have additive-combinatorial, algebraic, and ergodic-theoretic connections. Finally, the project will pursue various connections between problems in these areas. Specific questions to be attacked include a topological Dirac-type theorem for hypergraphs, investigating product-free sets living inside free structures, improving bounds for a few Ramsey-theoretic results of an additive-combinatorial flavor, and investigating the Ramsey-theoretic properties of non-abelian groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to investigate problems in extremal combinatorics and Ramsey theory in structured settings. At a very high level, this involved understanding and answering various basic questions of the form "how large can a combinatorial object X be subject to constraints Y on its structure?" 

The successful execution of the project bore multiple significant results, many of which were forecasted at the inception, but some of which surfaced unexpectedly as the research progressed. Some of the prominent highlights of the project are listed as follows:

  1. a new abstract (purely combinatorial) version of Halasz's theorem about arithmetic structure and anticoncentration,
  2. the resolution of Talagrand's threshold conjecture, and the refutation of a closely related conjecture regarding downset thresholds,
  3. a proof of a conjecture of Furedi from 1988 (appearing as Problem 91 in Ben Green's list of 100 open problems) about bisecting random graphs,
  4. a solution to a problem raised by Gowers in 2005 on topological analogues of Dirac's theorem,
  5. an answer to Linial's question from 2006 about topological Turan numbers
  6. the resolution of a problem of Alon--Kleitman--Thomassen--Saks--Seymour from 1987 about chromatic number andgraph connectivity, and
  7. the solution to a classical 1980's measure partitioning problem from algebraic topology using combinatorial methods.

The grant's financial support enabled the cultivation and training of two doctoral students, both of whom contributed significantly to the project's success. Furthermore, it provided the opportunity for eleven undergraduate students to engage in summertime research via the DIMACS REU program.

The findings and novel methodologies developed in the project were extensively communicated through various talks and lectures. Moreover, this funding paved the way for the creation of new lecture courses, which were developed and subsequently imparted at Rutgers. These teaching engagements have not only spread the newfound knowledge more broadly, but have also enriched the academic community and inspired potential future explorations in the field.

In conclusion, this project was a step forward in unraveling the mysteries of extremal combinatorics and Ramsey theory, contributing greatly to the body of mathematical knowledge and offering several pathways for future research.
